text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- A ceiling may be restored on the amount of forex anyone can take out for business or personal travel. The aim is to stem frivolous demand at the autonomous foreign exchange market.
- Swiss government apologises to Nigerian human rights activist Clement Nwankwo, who was allegedly tortured and convicted in Geneva last month over an allegation of theft.
- An unspecified number of the Nigerian-led West African ECOMOG troops head for Sierra Leone where soldiers seized power on Sunday.
- The International Labour Organisation may strip Nigeria of its voting rights over a debt of 60 million naira to the body.
- Nigerian Stock Exchange approves refinancing plan worth 516 million naira for six quoted firms.
- Nigeria may intervene in Sierra Leone to restore the democratic government toppled by soldiers on Sunday, according to a senior Nigerian military officer.
- The Nigerian government may have given approval to the oil ministry to invite bids for ultra deep offshore exploration for oil, industry sources say.

- Shell oil company will not resume oil production to the volatile Ogoniland until all issues in dispute there are resolved, says the outgoing chief executive of the company in Nigeria, Brian Anderson.
- The ailing Nigerian Newsprint Manufacturing Company is to be privatised, says national planning minister Ayo Ogunlade.
